title: Capital one sent a pre legal letter threatening to sue me, what does it mean?
question: I am on SSI an dI have only one car and I am 85 years old with no retirment income at all, can they garnsih my SSI and take my car?

It means that Capital One wants to be paid. Whether they can get that result is uncertain. Ultimately they can choose to file suit and take judgment. The most important reason for not proceeding directly to a lawsuit, and dancing around with meaningless demand formats like a "pre-legal letter" is that you are very likely "collection-proof." They know that their best chances of receiving payments is to get you to voluntarily do so.

Your needs will be best met be confirming that you are "collection-proof" and that Capital One-- even with a judgment-- can't disrupt your life. The expert is the experienced bankruptcy attorney. Many offer initial consultations on a no-cost/no-obligation basis, and the ethical ones don't "sell" bankruptcies; they give independent legal advice, including when a bankruptcy is not needed. If you do not knwo such a lawyer, use the attorney-finder at www.nacba.org.

Best wishes for a favorable outcome, and please remember to designate a best answer.

The creditor is seeking voluntary payment before bringing a collection lawsuit against you.

Nevertheless, SSI benefits are exempt from execution, levy, attachment, garnishment, or other legal process.

Most likely, any equity you may have in your car is protected by the statutory motor vehicle exemption. Debtors in California are permitted to protect up to $2,725 of equity in all their motor vehicles.
